info.game_comments:
2007 College Championship semifinal game 1.
From the University of Southern California.

(1, 1).clue: This Steinbeck novel begins, "To the red country and part of the gray country of Oklahoma, the last rains came..."

(2, 1).clue: Hilal, a pre-Islamic deity of Arabia, was god of one phase of this heavenly body

(3, 1).clue: This colorful river emptied into the sea until 1853, when its course shifted to empty into the Gulf of Chihli

(4, 1).clue: Franz Reichelt died after a 1912 jump from this tall Parisian structure testing his parachute-overcoat combo

(5, 1).clue: Tulane's football team plays its home games off campus at this facility that has a 9.7-acre roof

(6, 1).clue: Innocent & naive? You must be "wet behind" these

(1, 2).clue: A savage named John has educated himself by reading Shakespeare in "Brave New World" by this man

(2, 2).clue: The Hindu goddess Shatarupa was so beautiful, this creator god grew 4 heads so he could view her in all directions

(3, 2).clue: The border formalized between Mongolia & China in 1962 includes a 900-mile stretch through this desert

(4, 2).clue: Tradition holds that Aeschylus died when a bird dropped this reptile on his bald head to crack its shell

(5, 2).clue: Built in 1914, Palmer Stadium at this New Jersey university was the home of its football team for 82 years

(6, 2).clue: To pay or settle; it often precedes "the bill"

(1, 3).clue: In "The Prince" he wrote, "It is far safer to be feared than loved"

(2, 3).clue: A sabine god of war, Quirinus gave his name to one of the fabled hills of this city

(3, 3).clue: The Turfan Depression is China's lowest point; in 1951 this peak became its highest point

(4, 3).clue: Plutarch says that this king who lent his name to a type of costly victory died from being struck by a tile

(5, 3).clue: Fittingly, $57 million is what this food company is paying over 20 years to have its name on the Pittsburgh Panthers' field

(6, 3).clue: It can be a dialect or a bell clapper

(1, 4).clue: Perhaps the effort killed him--he died not long after completing his masterpiece "The Brothers Karamazov"

(2, 4).clue: Invoked by seal hunters, Nerrivik is the mother of all sea creatures as a goddess of this North American people

(3, 4).clue: China's Fertile Triangle lies between Nanjing, Hangzhou & this, the country's leading seaport

(4, 4).clue: In an automated factory in 1979, Robert Williams became one of the first men killed by one of these (shades of Asimov)

(5, 4).clue: This South Carolina school's Tigers play their home game in Memorial Stadium, aka "Death Valley"

(6, 4).clue: Your messy room at home might be one of these "of contention" with your parents

(1, 5).clue: The stories that Kenneth Grahame told his son about a mole & a toad became this 1908 classic

(2, 5).clue: Covering a lot of ground, this Greek counterpart of Diana was the goddess of childbirth & chastity

(3, 5).clue: This gulf is bordered by Luichow Peninsula & Hainan Island on the east & Vietnam on the west

(4, 5).clue: This playwright choked to death in 1983 at NYC's hotel Elysee; a character of his exits a streetcar at "Elysian Fields"

(5, 5).clue: Rupp Arena is the home court to this school's Wildcats basketball team

(6, 5).clue: A rounded mass of radicchio, for example

(1, 1).clue: A hot biomedical topic is apoptosis, the programmed "suicide" of these biological units

(2, 1).clue: They put on the "greatest show on earth" even before the Ringling brothers joined them

(4, 1).clue: It can follow smoke, cherry & incendiary

(5, 1).clue: Gaul had an area roughly including Luxembourg, Belgium, Germany w. of the Rhine & this tricolor flag-waving country

(6, 1).clue: From Jeopmark Cards: on the 2nd Sunday in May, you're the one we're thinking of, enjoy this very special holiday

(1, 2).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew plays with cool lab equipment.)  Infrasonics detects and interprets sounds we can't hear, like those produced by this kind of event; infrasonics would have helped the Pompeiians

(2, 2).clue: A book-publishing duo, or country music's Tim & Faith

(4, 2).clue: This fleshy growth atop a chicken's head comes in shapes such as buttercup & pea

(5, 2).clue: In "Commentaries on the Gallic War" he described Gaul as being inhabited by the Belgae, the Aquitani & the Gauls

(6, 2).clue: Hey, mon!  You be jahmmin' on May 23, Labour Day in dis country

(1, 3).clue: In 2006 a pulse of this type of beam sent a message a record 15 million miles to the MESSENGER spacecraft

(2, 3).clue: Company that introduced the first magnum revolver, the .357 in 1935

(4, 3).clue: Completed in 1932, it bears the inscription "Here rests in honored glory an American soldier known but to God"

(5, 3).clue: In 222 B.C.,  Romans defeated the Gauls in Italy, capturing the city of Mediolanum, now this northen city

(6, 3).clue: Ceremonies at the grave of Theodor Herzl are part of this country's Independence Day observation

(1, 4).clue: Invasion biology studies species like the brown tree this reptile, which wiped out 9 of Guam's 11 native bird species

(2, 4).clue: You've probably used some of their products: Crest, Gleem, Scope, Ivory

(4, 4).clue: A prosthesis is an artificial one

(5, 4).clue: In the Second Punic War, this Carthaginian made alliance with the Gallic Cenomani against the Romans

(6, 4).clue: On April 26, this country's Union Day commemorates the 1964 union of Zanzibar & Tanganyika

(1, 5).clue: These particles studied by astroparticle physics are the only ones in the nuclei of hydrogen atoms

(2, 5).clue: You can clean up on this one if you know it's the maker of the product seen here

(3, 5).clue: A USC grad:"Boyz n the Hood" & "2 Fast 2 Furious"

(4, 5).clue: Carpenters use this type of line with a weight on the end of it to determine a true vertical

(5, 5).clue: I, this Roman emperor, made Gallic nobility eligible for senate seats during my 41-54 A.D. reign

(6, 5).clue: On April 17 this state enjoys Verrazano Day

(0, 0).clue: Of all the U.S. states named after European monarchs, it's the one that reaches the farthest west
